Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of STS-PROM in Predicting Stroke and Neurocognitive Outcomes Post-TAVR

Trial_Design.evidence: This patient-level pooled analysis included 537 of 603 patients from four prospective trials

Participants.evidence: Participants were stratified into low (<4%), intermediate (4-8%), and high (>8%) STS risk groups.

Intervention.evidence: All patients underwent TAVR with predischarge diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (DW-MRI) and serial cognitive and neurologic assessments.

Objective.evidence: The study investigates whether the Society of Thoracic Surgeons Predicted Risk of Mortality (STS-PROM) predicts stroke and neurocognitive outcomes following transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR).

Method_Outcome.evidence: At 30 days, high-risk patients had higher rates of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, myocardial infarction, acute kidney injury, bleeding, and vascular complications.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This patient-level pooled analysis included 537 of 603 patients from four prospective trials

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 30 days, high-risk patients had higher rates of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, myocardial infarction, acute kidney injury, bleeding, and vascular complications.

Harms.evidence: At 30 days, high-risk patients had higher rates of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, myocardial infarction, acute kidney injury, bleeding, and vascular complications.

Trial_Registration.evidence: DEFLECT III (NCT02070731), NeuroTAVR (NCT02073864), REFLECT I (NCT02536196), REFLECT II (NCT02536196).
